hints.content: Start by considering how you would increment a number in a standard way. When you add one to the last digit, what happens if that digit is 9?
Think about how carrying works in addition. If you increment a digit and it becomes 10, you need to set that digit to 0 and carry over 1 to the next digit.
What if the last digit is not 9? In that case, you can simply increment that digit and return the modified array immediately.
Consider how to handle the carry when you reach the beginning of the array. If you carry out of the most significant digit, you'll need to add a new digit at the start of the array.
You can loop through the digits array from the last index to the first index. For each digit, check if it is 9 before deciding how to modify it.
Remember to check the array bounds while iterating. When you reach the first digit, if you still have a carry, you'll need to add a new digit at index 0.
Use a loop to iterate backward through the array. If you encounter a 9, set it to 0 and continue to the next digit. If you find a digit less than 9, just increment it and break out of the loop.
After the loop, check if you still have a carry. If so, insert 1 at the beginning of the array. This handles cases like incrementing 999 to 1000.
Make sure to return the modified array after processing all the digits. The return format should strictly match the input format, which is an array of integers.
Consider edge cases like a single digit 9 or an array with multiple 9s. How would your logic handle these scenarios? Think carefully about the carry propagation.

questionNotes: The input is an array of digits, where each digit is between 0 and 9.
The array does not contain leading zeros.
You need to return the resulting array after incrementing the integer represented by the digits.
